doc: The mob tried kill him once . He survived . And ever after that , we ' re was called Lucky . He became the godfather of the modern crime syndicate . Charles Lucky Luciano Climb the Mob Ladder He organized organized crime . He became an equal opportunity , my boss . But his creation of a murder - for - hire ring made him One of the deadliest . In the early 1930s , New York was a mob killing field . Out of this bloody chaos , there were more and more people . There emerged one cold - hearted , brilliant gangster named Lucky Luciano . He never looked in his eyes . It was strange , it was haunting . Weird Lucky connived and killed his way to the top when he got there he laid the foundation of modern organized crime , and the money poured in . He loved being Charles Lucky Luciano , the number one gangster in town . Luciano thrived on his reputation as the is the biggest racketeer and the most eligible bachelor in Manhattan . I ' d get like butterflies in my stomach . It was like a sexual Attraction . But Lucky paid the price for his notoriety when a crusading gangbuster named Thomas E . Dewey sent him off to prison . Behind bars , Lucky not only kept his position as chairman of the mob , but came to the aid of his beloved during World War II , greasing the way for U . S . troops invading his native Sicily . After the war , the gangster who loved America was forced to leave it behind . But Lucky would then prove that the mob , like other big businesses , was not troubled by national borders .

He had one of the really , really great talents and that unfortunately it was wasted . If it ' s Joe had written nothing abroad he would have still made perhaps the greatest contribution our publishing house that anyone has made . And that is to introduce us to Ernest Hemingway . When Scribner ' s published Hemingways , The Sun Also Rises in 1926 , The New York Times praised Hemingway ' s lean hard prose that put more conventional English to shame . Europe was really the making of Ernest Hemingway in his five years in Paris . Hemingway transformed himself from an eager hopeful to a world - class novelist elevating the lives of the expatriates into a masterpiece . Hemingway opened his last novel , A Movable Feast with a fitting quote from Gertrude Stein . You are all . A lost generation . The life of celebrity followed Ernest Hemingway along the left bank with hopeful young Americans emulating his success and his style . He was kind of a good old boy , had a high voice , and , Hi , I ' m Glen Campbell . In four decades he has sold over 45 million albums charted 75 country hits and traveled millions of miles singing some of the most listened to songs of all time . He wasn ' t . Your stand - up pop singer . He was this country guy doing these beautiful songs with all that energy he had on stage . doc: The number one gangster And he liked to be seen and celebrated . He was a great actor . He was always beautifully dressed expensive cars and jewelry expensive of women of places . He liked that high life and didn ' t want any intrusion on him . But in 1935 , one man would intrude on it and take away all the luxuries to which lucky Luciano had become a custom . His name ? Thomas E . Dewey . Just as Lucky Luciano ' s rise to power was a classic tale of mob intrigue his demise was one of the most celebrated examples of the crusade against organized crime . The Crusader was summoned with just as much ambition and cunning as Luciano himself . Thomas E . Dewey appointed in 1935 as special prosecutor in Manhattan . Dewey established his anti - mob headquarters on the 14th floor of the Woolworth building . His newsreels address the public ' s growing disenchantment with mob corruption . The real problem is to remove the influence of the racketeer from politics . Local authorities in New York and in almost every great city in the country . Hold office by grace of politicians who are in partnership with criminals . He was honest . It was forthright time and nothing to him . And his word meant everything . You can be trusted . And he was trusted . One of Dewey ' s first targets a powerful Jewish racketeer in the Bronx and a founding member of Luciano ' s committee Commission named Dutch Schultz . The word on the street was that Schultz was planning to kill Dewey . But mob boss Lucky Luciano and the rest of the commission members knew that killing Dewey would only bring more heat on the underworld .

Dewey . Just as Lucky Luciano ' s rise to power was a classic tale of mob intrigue his demise was one of the most celebrated examples the crusade against organized crime . The Crusader was summoned with just as much ambition and cunning as Luciano himself . Thomas E . Dewey appointed in 1935 as special prosecutor in Manhattan . Dewey established his anti - mob headquarters on the 14th floor of the Woolworth building . His newsreels address the public ' s growing disenchantment with mob corruption . The real problem is to remove the influence of the racketeer from politics . Local authorities in New York and in almost every great city in the country hold office by grace of politicians who are in partnership with criminals . He was honest . It was forthright time and nothing to him . And his word meant everything . He could be trusted , and he was trusted . One of Dewey ' s first targets , a powerful Jewish racketeer in the Bronx and a founding member of Luciano ' s committee Commission named Dutch Schultz . The word on the street was that Schultz planning to kill Dewey . But mob boss Lucky Luciano and the rest of the commission members knew that killing Dewey would only bring more heat on the underworld .

doc: Holmes and Freud were exact contemporaries and were developing very similar ideas at about the same time . For example , a significant idea in Freud ' s theory is the Oedipus complex . The idea male child develops jealousy and hatred of the father , there ' s an antagonism between father and son . Now if you look at the sixty stories of the Holmes canon No less than 23 have such a terrifying father figure in them who very often destroys or negates the son figure . In the adventure of the Priory School . Young Lord Arthur Sultire , whose sympathies are known to be strongly with his mother , suffers in this very way from his father The Duke of Holderness . Hardly anything is known about Holmes ' education in the glorious Scott . He told Watson that he ' d been at college , possibly Oxford or Cambridge , for only two years . He never said what subject he studied but he brought a formidable intellect to his work . He was the most perfect reasoning and observing machine the world has seen and he himself was most interested in the origins of his own ability in the Greek interpreter for example . He attributed it to heredity on the grounds that his brother , Mycroft possessed it to an even greater degree than he did . In a study in Scarlet on the other hand , he refers to Long habit which he said , enabled him to reach his lightning conclusions in acknowledging the roles both of inherited and acquired learning . He was one well ahead of today ' s research the origins of intelligence .

doc: You may leave , Scott and not come back for three weeks . But my mother and father never really got furious , you know , they just got exasperated and they would worry about his drinking . Of course because they were so fond of them . In July 1924 , Fitzgerald finally settled down and began working in earnest on the Great Gatsby . It was a time - consuming process for whenever Scott worked on a novel , he wrote many drafts of each chapter . If you read Fitzgerald ' s writing , you get the sense that he wrote in the same way that the birds sing , that it came to him very naturally . And that ' s not true birds sing , that it came to him very naturally , and that ' s not true . His first drafts are often undistinguished . And it was only through that laborious revision and the testing of the prose again and again against that marvelous ear that he had that he was able to achieve the beautiful effects that we so much admire him for . With Scott busy scribbling away , Zelda grew restless . She began spending long afternoons at the beach , where she met a handsome French aviator named Edouard Josin . In her four years of marriage , Zelda had flirted with other men , but he was the first she is said to have slept with . Scott was terribly upset when he found out , and though Zelda immediately ended the affair He never forgave her betrayal He seems to have felt that he and Zelda had a contract somehow , or an understanding that though she might be attractive to other men but she would never allow herself actually become involved with one , but this had happened and it created a sort of sadness in Fitzgerald that he never really recovered from .

But Morgan knew that the government didn ' t have time to sell bonds to the public . He was certain that his plan was the nation ' s best . Only hope . I have come down to Washington to see the president , and I ' m going to stay here until I see him . I think Pierpont Morgan certainly felt that he was the equal of the president of the United States . The next morning word came from the White House that Morgan would be received . During the meeting with the president and other cabinet members . The United States treasurer was given an urgent message . He pointed out that he knew of a $ 10 million draft about to be presented against the Treasury . If that $ 10 million draft is presented , you can ' t meet it , declared Morgan . doc: He really should have quit at that point . On the 27th of March 1918 , Richthofen shot down three British planes to bring his score to seven . More and more of his victims seem to be perishing in flames a fact that had begun to haunt Manfred . I could see the pilot and the observer twisting out of their airplane seats to escape the flames . The machine did not burn in the air but gradually burns on the way down . It fell out of control to the ground where it exploded and burned into ashes . It is a strange feeling . There once again a pair of men shot dead . They lie somewhere all burnt up and I myself sit here every day at the table and the food tastes as good as ever . Manfred von Richthofen . I ' m going to go . He had outlived all his rivals . Now there was no one left to challenge Richthofen as Germany ' s ace of aces yet he continued to fly in his relentless pursuit of immortality . He was idolized in the German press and for some time his commanders had been urging him to stop flying Even his mother had asked him to give it up . Would it please you more if I were in some safe place resting on my laurels ? Who would fight Sivir if we all felt like that ? Only the soldier in the trenches . When the professional fails at leadership , it will soon be as it is in Russia . Manfred von Richthofen By April 1918 , the Flying Circus had moved to Cappier Field , a desolate base with rain - soaked so tense serving for barracks that depressed Richthofen .

In June of 1934 , Richard Nixon graduated from Whittier a four - year honor student he applied for and received a scholarship to Duke University Law School . The competition here was much tougher than any he ' d faced before but his drive propelled him to third in his class . Richard Nixon was 24 now with his future course unset . He knew a life in politics appealed to him . He ' d been a master politician since high school but he didn ' t know how to go about it one alternate path he tried would have changed his future dramatically He attempted to join the FBI but he never heard back and assumed he ' d been turned down until many years later when J . doc: Fitzgerald completed the final drafts of the Great Gadsby . His work persevered in the face of an affair between his wife Zelda a French aviator . His faith in marriage shattered . Fitzgerald was drawn to the second most influential woman from his years in France , Sarah Murphy . A young woman lay under a roof of umbrellas making out a list of things from a book open on the sand . Her bathing suit was pulled off her shoulder and her back . A ruddy orange - brown set off by a string of creamy pearls . Shown in the sun . Her face was hard . Lovely and pitiful . Fitzgerald was as entranced by Sarah ' s Irish beauty and her fierce intelligence as Pablo Picasso had been before him . Bread as a Manhattan sophisticated . Cosmopolitan Sarah Murphy abandoned the life of her parents by marrying Gerald Murphy . An intense Yale graduate who preferred the art of living over running his father ' s luxury goods emporium . Gerald had the good sense to dismiss the schoolboy attractions of Fitzgerald as sad . Sentimental Disturbances . Gerald Murphy treated life with such a sense of style that Picasso remarked there is American elegance . His complexion was reddish and weather - burned . So was his short hair . His eyes were of a bright , Hard Blue . His voice with some faint Irish melody running through it . Wound the world . Gerald had a transformation when he arrived in Paris in 1921 . He saw in a gallery window of Picasso and Braque one grease and he decided That was what he wanted to do with his life painting , he told Sarah .

That was one reason people feared big business . So I think that that is part of what made people so angry at Rockefeller . I ' m not sure . The president Teddy Roosevelt was the point man in the effort to bring Rockefeller down In spite of his own privileged upbringing , Roosevelt was an enemy of the big business trade trusts . He knew the nation was more than ready to rein the men , and so he decided to go after one of the biggest of them all , South Dakota ' s largest Standard Oil and its director John D . Rockefeller became the kind of lightning rod for all the things that were wrong with industrial development . doc: Luciano was a regular on the Manhattan social scene . The upper crust didn ' t mind that during business hours Lucky was a cold - blooded killer extorting millions . Go downtown and see a real - life gangster and probably fawn and I wouldn ' t have been surprised if they had asked for his autograph . That ' s the kind of figure had become . The newspaper people You gotta remember that New York City had nine newspapers in that era . All the newsmen knew him and it was a wave and a hello and hi , you ' re lucky and so on . It was very dangerous . Lansky always said they ' ll nail you for this inviting trouble that you don ' t need but he loved being Charles Lucky Luciano . The number one gangster And he liked to be seen and celebrated . He was a great actor . He was always beautifully dressed expensive of cars and jewelry expensive of women of places . He liked that high life and didn ' t want any intrusion on it . But in 1935 , one man would intrude on it and take away all the luxuries to which Lucky Luciano had become a custom . His name ? Thomas E . Dewey . Just as Lucky Luciano ' s rise to power was a classic tale of mob intrigue . His demise was one of the most celebrated examples of the crusade against organized crime . In the wireless room , Phillips has a two - hour window to send every message while the Titanic is in range of the Cape Race receiver at Newfoundland . He is interrupted by the fifth and the most critical ice warning of the day . It is from another ship . The SS Massaba . The masaba gives the precise location of an area containing icebergs . Only 50 miles away from the Titanic . This would alert the captain that the Titanic is heading straight towards the iceberg . But the warning comes without the critical MSG prefix . Phillips interprets the message as non - urgent and goes back to sending passenger messages . The closest ship to the Titanic , the Californian , also sends a message . She has decided to stop for the night because of ice . But their wireless operator does not wait for Phillips to stop sending his messages and overrides it with a powerful signal .

After being hired for several small roles , his first big break came when he was cast as Benvolio in the company ' s landmark production of Romeo and Juliet . doc: His father , Frederick , was a successful stockbroker whose gregarious and whimsical personality delighted his young son . Fred ' s mother Dorothy was a strong - willed and artistic woman who had created the popular comic book comic strip Sunny Gym . But once her son was born , Fred became the center of her universe . She had tried have children before him and I think two or three had died . So he was sort of a miracle baby for her she just showered him with praise and love and attention . Doted on by his mother , Fred enjoyed all the benefits that wealth allowed as he came of age surrounded by America ' s aristocracy . I remember Fred telling me that in wintertime his dad used to have a house down in Palm Beach in Florida right next to Joe Kennedy ' s . They moved in those kinds of circles goals . But in 1935 , the eight - year - old ' s idyllic existence ended when his father unexpectedly died after a routine sinus operation . Shattered by the loss of the man he adored the lonely youngster often withdrew into an imaginary world he created in his sketches a talent he shared with his mother . He was always drawing , and I ' m sure that his mother loved it , since she was a cartoonist herself , and so she would encourage him to draw encourage him to do that . You couldn ' t keep a pen out of his hands . Fred ' s mother also nurtured him through his awkward years at school when a sudden growth spurt set the adolescent apart from his peers . Can you imagine a kid who was that tall and gangly ? and you ' d think he would be ostracized more than embraced .

doc: After giving so much of himself , it was hard for Scott to reach the end only to find his books no longer in print and his name forgotten . It wasn ' t until the 1950s that readers rediscovered his books and critics began to rank Fitzgerald among the most famous among the best writers of his generation . His books now sell hundreds of thousands of copies a year . I think Gatsby alone sells over 300 , 000 thousand copies a year . It ' s probably among the most popular if you go by sales of any American novel . Over the years Fitzgerald ' s reputation has continued to grow . Today , his place among America ' s literary legends is secure and he is widely admired by many modern writers . I ' ve been interested in Fitzgerald ever since I was a teenager and read his novel , The Great Gatsby . It taught me a lot and it fortified my own ambition to become a writer of fiction . It also taught me not to try to become a writer of fiction like Fitzgerald because he has a connection with the English language which I knew even then . I would not possess . In my mind he stands out because is not like Hemingway , Mailer some of that Bigfoot . Male authors that were his contemporaries . He ' s got a different sensibility . He ' s more interested in love and desire and domesticity domestic life and suffer women writers . He ' s an accessible male writer . As part of the continuing rehabilitation of F . Scott Fitzgerald ' s reputation , In 1996 , the country celebrated his 100th birthday commemorative stamp .

doc: One enormous contribution was in conservation , a field he long loved . He bought up the entire Jackson Hole of Wyoming and donated it to the new National Park Service . For Junior , giving back to the nation that had been so good to him was a fundamental principle without certain pre - principles . Life has little meaning . I believe that every right in implies a responsibility every and an obligation . Saving the Redwoods of California was another of the conservation projects he undertook after 1924 . He purchased in whole or in part Acadia National Park , Great Smoky Mountains National Park , Yosemite and Yellowstone National Park . And he believed that at every plant and every rock and every tree and every flower had spirit in it . He wanted people to experienced the natural world and he felt Those things were a manifestation of the divine as he understood it . And at the height of the depression he began a project back in New York that was wildly out of step with the battered economy , Rockefeller Center . He saw this is an opportunity to do something that would be seen as an act of faith in the darkest time in American history and indeed . Rockefeller Center is saying America is going to revive , America is going to dominate , America is going to prevail . We are all determined that our economic machine shall work . There is a very close relationship ship between our national state of mind and our general economic I think he took an enormous personal pride that he put tens of thousands of people to work .

The majority of the crew and all the passengers believe that the damage to the ship is minimal unaware that the ship is letting in water at 400 tons a minute . Ismay ' s decision to lower the bulkheads means the ship is flooding rapidly . With higher bulkheads , the flooding in each compartment would have taken longer to fill and overflow into the next But they didn ' t lower the front bulkhead because they believed it to be the crucial one . The designers were anticipating any collision to be head - on . The water wouldn ' t flood beyond the front collision bulkhead . But they hit the iceberg ' s side on and the sides weren ' t designed to take the force of an impact .

doc: First , there was the remarkable visit to China a nation Nixon had long painted as America ' s implacable foe . In February of 1972 , Richard Nixon met with , drank with , and dined with leaders of the world ' s most populous communist nation . He would later regard the trip as the high point of his presidency and it was met with near universal acclaim . Then in May of 1972 Richard Nixon went to the Soviet Union signed a strategic arms limitation treaty . A first big step toward taming the arms race between the superpowers . It was part of a policy to warm relations with the land Nixon had always seen as profoundly evil and with detente . A backing away from Cold War brinksmanship , the whole world breathed easier . In his policy toward the Soviets and China , Nixon gained two ends . On its own , the policy advanced Richard Nixon ' s goal of world peace but it was also geopolitics at its most sophisticated . Fearful of each other , both Russia and China were more than ready to make America an ally . I think that the opening of China and the establishment of the Soviet Union It was first of all an act of political courage Nixon ' s part . It was very high - risk politics . And it was the product of very hard thinking on Nixon ' s part . About the shape of the world and the shape of the United States and where we are in the world and what we need To do and what kind of world do we want five and ten and twenty ? in 20 years from now .

doc: Richard Nixon beat Helen Douglas by a wide margin but she had her revenge . During the campaign she characterized him with a nickname And it was one that would stay with him forever , Tricky Dick . 1952 , when the first TV spots ever made were for Eich Eisenhower . You like Ike , I like Ike , everybody likes Ike . For president , I believe in the future of the United States of America . General Dwight Eisenhower was the larger than life hero of Senator was selected as his running mate . Nixon was chosen not because Eisenhower thought he was the best man , but because he was a the right balance for the ticket and uh Eisenhower always had a certain lofty distaste for some of the tactics that Nixon used . The first big test of their relationship came less than two months into the campaign when a front page story in the New York Post claimed Nixon had a secret $ 18 , 000 fund for personal expenses paid for by millionaire backers . There were calls for Ike to drop Nixon from the ticket . Pat Nixon and urge your husband to fight . She said that no , Dick , we both know what you have to do . You have to fight it through to the end . And my father told me years later that those were the words he really needed to hear then . You are about to hear a report from Senator Richard Nixon . Nominee for the office of vice president . Though Ike did not rush to Nixon ' s support , he did arrange for an unprecedented half hour of TV time in which Nixon could defend himself against the charges .

doc: Dorothy reached out to find love and acceptance in all the wrong places . She never was fulfilled and never really valued herself and never valued her life In 1958 , Samuel Goldwyn was producing a big budget film of Porgy and Bess . But many in the black community felt that even Gershwin ' s music Couldn ' t overshadow the movie ' s negative stereotyping that they had fought so hard to overcome . Dorothy , who had not had a starring role in the four years since Carmen Jones , Signed on to play Bess for $ 75 , 000 . Part of our community thought that she was selling out It ' s just a shame that Hollywood created this beautiful , glamorous , talented movie star , but then didn ' t know what to do with her . It was already a tense set when the film ' s director was fired and replaced with Dorothy ' s rejected lover , Otto Preminger . He was a great director . But you simply brutal and Dorothy was this delicate beauty and she was delicate in temperament . Nothing she did was right with him and he would stop her and stop her until she didn ' t know her lies , I mean until she really could not function . Depressed and exhausted . Dorothy dreamed of a life out of the spotlight and turned her attention to Jack Dennison a white former maitre d ' htel who had been pursuing her for years . He looked like a Greek god . And she worshipped beauty . I didn ' t like it . Mr . Dennison didn ' t like what he was about . He was a very cruel person and She was a masochist .

He was called a lot of other things too . Perhaps no other American family has been so severely criticized for the way they made their fortune or so lavishly praised the way they have spent it . With their noses in the air A John D . Rockefeller , I believe , was America ' s first billionaire . He had to have it all . And to get it all , he moved beyond the law . I do not believe that great grandfather went beyond the law but he certainly flexed his muscles . He became the kind of lightning rod for all the things that were wrong with industrial development . Rockefeller Once , the name meant ruthlessness and oil . Later , public service and philanthropy on a grand scale from Yosemite National Park to the United Nations . What has never changed what the family name has always evoked . Wealth and power . Money is like Sex power lusts its appetite and it can destroy I mean that ' s what ' s unique about the Rockefellers , that money . It was a painful legacy for them , but it never destroyed really any of them .

doc: It ' s just that I think in very simple ways and what I have to say as I put very simply . He was writing about this group of kind of lost generation people and trying to give a portrait of a group . Americans were fascinated by the lost generation , although like Gertrude Stein , many criticized them lack of morality . No critics were harsher than his own family . His mother , Grace , sent him a newspaper clipping stating that the Sun Also Rises was out of focus and wrote , Surely you have other words in your vocabulary besides damn and bitch . In defense of his work , Hemingway responded . I ' m trying in all my stories to get the feeling of the actual life across , not to just depict life or critical thinking criticize it but to actually make it alive . You can ' t do this without putting in the bad and the ugly as well as what is beautiful because if it is all beautiful , you can ' t believe it . Things aren ' t that way . Soon after The Sun Also Rises was published . Hemingway had another falling out . This time with his early mentor Gertrude Stein when they wrote about one another afterwards . It was a battle of egos . Hemingway claimed The Sun Also Rises taught her how to write dialogue and that she was jealous because he had surpassed her teaching . Stein retaliated in her book , Autobiography of Alice B . Toklas , where she made quips about his talent and challenged his masculinity . To Stein , the woman who wrote , a rose is a rose .

doc: Hemingway had an unwavering faith in him in his new novel and he told his publisher Charles Scribner that if his novel wasn ' t good , Scribner could hang him by the neck until dead . Adriana ' s artwork was featured on the cover of his novel titled across the river and into the trees . EB White of the New Yorker felt a more appropriate title was , across the street and into the grill . It was by all the critics estimation an inferior war . And until that time , I don ' t think Ernest had ever had a bad review . Not only were the reviews bad , but quite vicious . And many of the critics said that at that point Hemingway had become a parody of himself that he can no longer right in a way that would intrigue and entertain the people who had come to expect a certain of literature from him . After its publication , Adriana denied that she ever had a sexual relationship with Hemingway . Still , she and her mother went on a trip to visit Hemingway in Cuba where reporters eagerly awaited to see Hemingway ' s young obsession . Adriana and her mother returned to Italy in embarrassment . I saw him in Cuba soon after that and he was very deeply hurt by the critics . But he said , I ' ll tell you something . So the time to prove what you ' re doing you ' re made of is not when you ' re at the top of your form . But when you ' ve been knocked on your ass , you have to get up off the canvas .

doc: Her real name was Ardis Ankerson . And before long , she and Bill were inseparable . She had kind of a quiet sophistication to her . I think she represented a serious side a more conservative side . And she was kind of cute . On July 13th , 1941 , deftly dodging the press , 23 - year - old Bill eloped to Las Vegas with 24 - year - old Ardis . Holden took his role as head of the family seriously . He adopted Virginia , Ardis ' s three - year - old daughter from her first marriage and proudly insisted that they live off his weekly income of $ 150 despite the fact that his film star wife earned five times more than he did . In December 1941 , the United States declared war . And like thousands of young men , Bill ' s 20 - year - old brother Robert left to fight in the Pacific . Holden hungered to join him in battle and became the first married film star to enlist . But because of his Hollywood status , He was assigned to a public relations unit on a base in Texas . On November 17th , 1943 , Ardis gave birth to a son Peter Westfield . But only two months later , the couple ' s joy was overshadowed by tragedy . When Bill received the news that his brother had been shot down over the South Pacific Ocean Bob was the reasonable balanced one , the one who could bring things together . He was apparently a warm engaging person . I think it Absolutely bewildered Bill . The thought that they would never see him again . Holden was overcome with guilt . His brother had died while he was kept safe and sound in the Army ' s motion picture unit .

doc: But at the age of 40 William Holden knew that Hollywood stardom would never be enough . By 1958 , William Holden was feeling self - conscious about his profession . Now 40 , he thought that acting was a frivolous way for a grown man to make a living and he wanted to prove his worth in more serious ventures . He invested heavily in manufacturing companies in Asia , and now referred to himself as a businessman . And he used to say to me , hell , I ' m not an actor . He had a sense that maybe the success we ' ve had or the good fortunes we ' ve had , we don ' t know recognition . It ' s fraudulent . And there was a sense of him undeserving and Bill Holden . In the summer of 1959 , Holden surprised his family when he announced that they were moving to Lausanne , This decision was made without are having anything to say about it . Just up and wet . But the move did little to help Bill and Ardis ' s difficult 18 - year marriage and he once again began drinking heavily . He traveled restlessly from one continent to another . doc: Her idea was that If you talked about just the surface of a person or an object , that you would create this verbal cubism . If I told him , would he like it ? Would he like it if I told him ? Would he like it ? Would Napoleon , would Napoleon , would , would he like it ? So it led to a kind of style like if Picasso would Picasso did Picasso there ' s all these sort of repetitious , incantatory phrases . Would you like it if I told him ? if I told him , if Napoleon . The better - known work would be Picasso ' s portrait of Stein . After 90 sittings with Stein , an exasperated Picasso left her portrait unfinished , exclaiming , When I look at you I no longer see you . Finally , months later , he presented Stein with her completed portrait . A famous line she has said remarked , It doesn ' t look like me . Picasso replies It will . Thirty years later , Stein wrote , It is the only reproduction of me which is still Our image of that salon is that it is the beginning of true modernism . And of course if you go to the modern collection in the Metropolitan Museum now the first image you see absolutely appropriately is the Picasso ' s Puppet of Gopinstein as a literary hub for Americans in Paris . Stein ' s salon was surpassed only by the English language bookshop on 12 Rue de L ' Odion and that was the bookshop of Sylvia Beach , Shakespeare and Company and it became a literary center . It became a crossroads . Sylvia Beach had a devotional love for literature and those who wrote it leaving her life in America as a minister ' s daughter .
